network.title: food shortages

factbox.description: In 2010, the global price of wheat doubled after poor harvests in Russia, China and the Ukraine. The high price of bread that year became an aggravating factor in the social unrest known as the Arab Spring.

network.credits: Mint Images/Frans Lanting/Science Source, Jim West/Science Source, Earl Roberge/Science Source

nodes.label: Heat waves
nodes.description: Extreme heat waves become longer and more severe
Soil dries from heat and lack of rain
Dry soil produces fewer crops
Food shortages contribute to food insecurity and famine
Cost of food increases

network.title: political conflicts

factbox.description: A series of droughts between 2006 and 2011 devastated rural areas in Syria. Unemployed refugees fled to the cities, contributing to civil war and disputes over refugees in Europe.

network.credits: NOOR/Redux Pictures, Sarah Errington/UIG/Science Source, A. Hart-Davis/Science Source, Associated Press

nodes.label: Droughts
nodes.description: Droughts become longer and more frequent
Crop failures and famines
People flee drought-stricken areas to become "climate refugees"
Hunger and unemployment fuel political instability, violence and war
Emigrants pour into neighboring countries

network.title: diseases spreading

factbox.description: Parts of Argentina have already seen a surge of malaria as the climate warms and mosquito ranges expand.

network.credits:
Sciepro/Science Source, Science Artwork/Science Source,
Andrew/Centers for Disease Control & Prevention/Science Source, Richard T. Nowitz/Science Source

nodes.label: Habitat change
nodes.description: Insect and microbe ranges expand
Disease-causing organisms move into new places
Lyme disease could spread as ticks' ranges expand
Mosquitoes could spread malaria and dengue fever to new areas
Waterborne diseases such as cholera could spread as flooding and rain runoff contaminate water
Toxic algal blooms could contaminate seafood
Yellow fever, Chagas's disease, schistosomiasis and other warm-weather diseases could all become more common

network.title: invasive species

factbox.description: Many birds have already shifted the timing of their migrations in response to climate change.

network.credits: Nigel Cattlin/Science Source, Oliver Gerhard/ImageBroker/AGE Fotostock, Samuel R. Maglione/Science Source

nodes.label: seasons change
nodes.description: Winters are warmer and spring starts earlier
Leaves appear earlier
Leaf-eating insects multiply sooner
Birds must migrate earlier to find insects to eat
Plant, insect and bird ranges shrink or move, when possible
Invasive pests such as bark beetles could devastate forests
Trees could die when ranges shift
Wildfires become larger and more frequent

network.title: displaced people

factbox.description: The Solomon Islands, an island nation in the Pacific Ocean, has already lost six islands to rising waters.

network.credits: Edna Douthat/Science Source, Michael McCoy/Science Source, Dr. Neil Overy/Science Source

nodes.label: sea level rise
nodes.description: Ice-sheet and glacial melting quickens, and warming oceans expand
Coastal cities threatened by floods and storm surges
Many cannot afford protective barriers to rising seas
Millions of people in poorer areas could be displaced
Low-lying islands could disappear entirely
